from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Porter
Democracy
Dear Chair

I refer to your emails of 9 April 2020 and 17 September 2020 regarding petition number EN1314, which requests that Australia seek to insert Harry and Meghan, Duke and Duchess of Sussex as its King and Queen.
I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this petition to my attention and apologise for the delay in responding.

The preamble to the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act refers to the historical fact of the agreement to federate under the 'Crown of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland'. Covering clause 2 of that Act states that references to 'the Queen' extend to 'Her Majesty's heirs and successors in the sovereignty of the United Kingdom'.

The passing of the British Empire has meant that the Queen is now 'sovereign' of a number of separate and independent nations, including the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada and New Zealand. It is now generally accepted that, as Queen of Australia, the Queen holds an entirely distinct position from that which she holds as Queen of the United Kingdom (or any other country). A former Chief Justice of Australia, the Hon Sir Harry Gibbs, stated that '[t]he allegiance which Australians owe to Her Majesty is owed not as British subjects but as subjects of the Queen of Australia' (Pochi v Macphee (1982) 151 CLR 101 at 109). It is quite clear both that the current Queen of Australia (and of the United Kingdom) is a successor to Queen Victoria and that references in the Australian Constitution to 'the Queen' encompass references to the current Queen. This is reflected in the Royal Style and Titles Act 1973, under which the current Royal Style and Titles in Australia are 'Elizabeth the Second, by the Grace of God Queen of Australia and Her other Realms and Territories, Head of the Commonwealth' .
The Government has no proposal to alter the Royal succession to the throne in Australia to install the Duke and Duchess of Sussex as its King and Queen.

Succession to the Crown was altered in some respects in Australia (as it also was in the United Kingdom and in other Commonwealth Realms) by the Successionto the Crown Act 2015 (Cth). That Act made three reforms concerning the succession to the Crown consistent with changes enacted in the United Kingdom in the Succession to the Crown Act 2013 (UK). Those reforms are: ,
to bring to an end the system of male preference primogeniture so that the order of succession will be determined simply by order of birth
to remove the statutory provisions under which anyone who marries a person of the Roman Catholic faith loses their place in the line of succession, and
to limit the requirement that the Sovereign consent to the marriage of a descendant of his late Majesty King George the Second in certain circumstances.

The Succession to the Crown Act 2015 was enacted by the Commonwealth Parliament following requests to that course enacted by all state Parliaments, for the purpose of section 5l(xxxviii) of the Constitution.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Porter
COVID-19
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 referring to me a petition concerning the risks to the integrity of Australian democracy and accountability regarding the exercise of executive powers and spending of public money during the COVID-19 period. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

As you can appreciate, the first priority of any government is the security and protection of the Australian people. A pandemic moves at an exponential pace. A loss of days can result in untold loss and suffering. At the time of writing, in excess of 911,000 lives have been lost worldwide. Sadly that includes over 800 Australians. Australia can be proud of its efforts to date. There is a long way to go, but all levels of government have worked tirelessly on protecting our people.

The pandemic has required that Australia act with an unwavering focus on protecting our people. Parliament, like the rest of Australian society, is not immune to the dangers posed by COVID-19. The Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate are strong custodians for the institution of Parliament. They have worked exceptionally hard to ensure the Parliamentary precincts are COVID safe. The Presiding Officers have ensured the Parliament acted as a role model for other work places whilst ensuring the Parliament's vital work did not suffer.

In relation to the sittings of the Parliament, prior to the COVID-19 crisis the parliamentary calendar for 2020 had 72 sitting days for the House of Representatives, and 57 sitting days for the Senate plus 19 days for Estimates hearings. The pandemic forced changes to the parliamentary calendar - like it did to just about every public gathering in the world, including our courts.

The calendar has been adjusted on a number of occasions - and now has 58 days of sitting of the House, and 46 sitting days for the Senate plus 15 days for Estimates hearings. This was about keeping Australians safe.

By way of comparison, there are now planned to be 58 sitting days (House of Representatives) for 2020, compared to 45 days in 2019 (election year), 65 days in 2018 and 64 days in 2017. This means that the Parliament will sit for a broadly similar number of days as in previous years when Australia was not facing the challenges of a global pandemic.

The Government welcomes scrutiny. In addition to the ordinary mechanisms for the Parliament to hold the Government to account, a number of measures have emerged in response to COVID-19. For example, the Senate has established a Select Committee on the Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Committee, like other Senate Committees, has the full range of powers to call for documents and witnesses, which will be necessary for its inquiry. The terms of reference for the Committee are broad, as is the Committee's membership. The Chair of the Committee is a Senator from the Opposition, and it includes two Government Senators, two other Senators from the Opposition, one Senator from the Australian Greens and Senator Jacqui Lambie. The Government supported the establishment of this Committee and considers it is appropriate to review the actions and decisions taken by the Government during this pandemic.
Thank you again for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Porter
Teachers
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 24 August 2020 referring a number of petitions (listing enclosed), received by the Standing Committee on Petitions, regarding the Literacy and Numeracy Test for Initial Teacher Education Students (the test).

For all teachers, no matter the year level or subjects they teach, strong personal literacy and numeracy skills form an essential part of the attributes and skills needed to be effective in the classroom. While personal literacy and numeracy skills are only one element of what makes a good teacher, they are critical to fostering the development of strong personal literacy and numeracy in students.

The requirement that students undertaking an initial teacher education program have personal literacy and numeracy skills that are in the top 30 per cent of the adult population was introduced by agreement of all education ministers. The test requirement has been implemented through the Accreditation of Initial Teacher Education Programs in Australia: Standards and Procedures (the Standards and Procedures) since 2011, with the test being used since 2016 as the means for demonstrating a student has achieved this standard.

Under Standard 3.5, higher education providers have a key role in the process. The Standard states that 'Entrants to initial teacher education will possess levels of personal literacy and numeracy broadly equivalent to the top 30 per cent of the population. Providers who select students who do not meet this requirement must establish satisfactory arrangements to ensure that these students are supported to achieve the required standard before graduation.'

As the test requirement is related to accreditation of initial teacher education programs and/or registration as a teacher, each state or territory is responsible for imposing the requirement relating to the test in that jurisdiction under the relevant state or territory legislation. This includes specifying how the test interacts with progression through an initial teacher education program and/or subsequent registration as a teacher. As a result, some states and territories have different requirements regarding the test. Students should contact the teacher regulatory body in their state or territory to confirm specific jurisdictional requirements, including requirements to sit the test at a particular point in their program. As it is states and territories who manage accreditation of initial teacher education courses, the Australian Government is not able to grant exemptions to the test requirement.

Even in these unprecedented times, maintaining an expectation of high-quality teaching is important. As such, the requirement for initial teacher education students to meet the standard of the test prior to graduation remains in place. The Australian Council for Education Research, which administers the test, has put in place arrangements so that all people who need to sit the test in 2020 can do so. Further information about arrangements for the test is available online at https://teacheredtest.acer.edu.au/.

Candidates are allowed up to three opportunities to sit the test. In special and/or extenuating circumstances, higher education providers may consider that individual students should be provided additional test attempts up to a maximum of five (including the initial three attempts).

For students who have a disability or health-related need which might interfere with their ability to sit the test, ACER continues to offer reasonable adjustments to provide students with appropriate testing conditions. Further information on the reasonable adjustments application process can be found at teacheredtest.acer.edu.au/register/reasonable-adjustments.
To assist candidates to prepare to sit the test, ACER offers a range of resources on the test website, including:
full practice tests, retired test questions, and sample and practice questions, which are available at teacheredtest.acer.edu.au/prepare/practice-material
a Described Proficiency Scale outlining the skills assessed by the test, which is available at teacheredtest.acer.edu.au/results/described-proficiency-scales
information on interpreting test results, at teacheredtest.acer.edu.au/results.

With regard to suggestions that the test be used as an entry requirement, universities do have the option to use the test as a selection tool; however, to date none have elected to use it in this way. Universities are responsible for the selection of students into initial teacher education and for ensuring their programs adequately prepare all students to meet the test standard. Students are strongly encouraged to seek support and remedial assistance from their higher education provider as appropriate.

The Australian Government actively monitors the delivery of all national programs and commissioned an independent review of the implementation of the test. Decisions regarding the LANTITE review are matters for all education ministers through Education Council and it is anticipated that it will be considered in December.
The Australian Government remains committed to ensuring high quality graduates enter Australian classrooms. The test is an important component of providing this assurance.

Further information regarding the test is available on the Department of Education, Skills and Employment's website at https://www.education.gov.au/literacy-and-numeracy-test-initial­teacher-education-students.
Yours sincerely
Services Australia
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 24 August 2020 to the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Minister for Government Services, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, concerning a petition received on the social security deeming rates. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibility, your letter has been forwarded to me for reply.

The deeming rules are used to assess income from financial investments for social security purposes. Financial investments include all bank accounts, managed investments, shares and most superannuation. To calculate the investment income assessed, deeming rates are applied to the total market value of a person's financial investments. The actual returns from the person's investments are not used for income assessment.
Available returns from bank accounts, term deposits and market-linked investments, including shares and superannuation, are considered when setting the deeming rates.
The deeming rates are continually monitored to ensure they are in line with available returns.
Currently, a deeming rate of 0.25 per cent applies to the first:
$53,000 of a single recipient's total financial investments,
$88,000 of a pensioner couple's total financial investments,
$44,000 of total financial investments for each member of a couple who receives an allowance payment.

A deeming rate of 2.25 per cent applies to financial investments above these amounts. The thresholds at which the upper deeming rate begins to apply are reviewed in line with the Consumer Price Index in July each year.

The lower deeming rate is designed to reflect available returns from safe and accessible investments, such as savings accounts. The upper deeming rate is designed to reflect that as a person's assets increase, they often have some higher-return investments that may have limited accessibility or some additional risk.

The two-rate structure of deeming rules means that the upper deeming rate only applies to a portion of a social security recipient's financial investments, rather than all of their financial assets. For example, under the current deeming rates, a single pensioner with $100,000 in financial assets would only need to achieve a rate of return of 1.2 per cent across their investment portfolio to match the deeming rates.

The current system of deeming was implemented in the 1990s in response to concerns from retirees and advocacy groups. It is designed to be simple, fair and reduce the extent that payments received from Centrelink may vary - an important feature for many income support recipients. By treating all financial investments in the same way, the deeming rules also encourage people to choose investments on their merit, not on how they may affect their rate of payment.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
from the Minister for Families and Social services, Senator Ruston
Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020 enclosing Petition EN1581 concerning temporary visa holders seeking exemptions from Australia's travel restrictions. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, from 1 February 2020, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions to curb the introduction and spread of COVID-19 in Australia. From 20 March 2020, travel restrictions have been in place prohibiting travel into Australia of all foreign nationals, unless they fall within certain exempt categories.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia , and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

State and territory governments have taken decisions to impose health restrictions such as mandatory two weeks quarantine for all international arrivals. Unfortunately, limited hotel rooms have been made available for quarantine purposes by the state governments who administer the quarantine arrangements. The problem has been compounded by arbitrary state border closures where returning state residents are placed in hotel quarantine, taking places that would otherwise have been utilised by citizens returning from overseas.

Decisions to grant exemptions must be balanced against the Government 's intent for imposing the travel restrictions, that is, the potential health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers.
The travel restrictions for persons coming to Australia do not apply to:
an Australian citizen or a permanent resident of Australia;
an immediate family member of an Australian citizen or permanent resident;
a New Zealand citizen usually resident in Australia and their immediate family members;
a diplomat accredited to Australia (holding a subclass 995 visa) (effective 11 July 2020);
a traveller transiting Australia for 72 hours or less (effective 11 July 2020);
airline crew;
maritime crew including marine pilots; and
recruited under the Government approved Seasonal Worker Program or Pacific Labour Scheme.

The Commissioner of the Australian Border Force (ABF), Mr Michael Outram APM, or Home Affairs Departmental or ABF decision-makers may consider requests for travel on a case by case basis where there are compelling circumstances.

The exemption request should be accompanied by the individual's details, case information and supporting statement. It is important that people seeking an exemption provide evidence of a compelling case in accordance with one of the following, categories:
a person travelling at the invitation of the Government or a state or territory government authority for the purpose of assisting in the COVID-19, response;
a person providing critical or specialist medical services,. including air ambulance, medical evacuations and delivering critical medical supplies;

a person with critical skills required to maintain the supply of essential goods and services, such as in medical technology, critical infrastructure, telecommunications, engineering and mining, supply chain logistics, aged care, agriculture, primary industry, food production, and the maritime industry;

a person delivering services in sectors critical to Australia's economic recovery, such as financial technology, large scale manufacturing, film, media and television production and emerging technology, where no Australian worker is available;
providing critical skills in religious or theology fields;
sponsored by your employer to work in Australia in an occupation on the Priority Migration Skilled Occupation List;
a person whose entry would otherwise be in the national interest, supported by the Government or a state or territory government authority;
military personnel, including those who form part of the Status of Forces Agreement, Commonwealth Armed Forces, Asia Pacific Forces and Status of Armed Forces Agreement;
a student completing year 11 and 12, with support from the relevant state or territory government; or
travel for compassionate and compelling reasons.

On 17 September 2020, the Department published the Commissioner's Inwards Decision making statement, Commissioner's Guidelines and two Operational Directives on the Department's website. The Commissioner previously issued guidelines to decision-makers in July, which were later published to increase transparency about the process, and to assist individuals requesting an exemption from Australia's travel restrictions.
The Department and the ABF are finalising the majority of inwards travel exemption requests within seven days, noting that some complex requests may take longer.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
For the latest information and advice from the Government in relation to the outbreak of COVID-19, please visit: https://www.australia.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1581 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 24 August 2020 to the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, and Minister for Government Services, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, concerning the petition on the Age Pension age (EN1584). As the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibility, your email has been forwarded to me for reply.

There is no official retirement age in Australia. Retirement decisions are a matter for each individual. Australians are living longer than before and the Government is committed to ensuring the Age Pension is sustainable and future demand can be met. To receive the Age Pension, a person must also satisfy the residence and means test requirements.

The Government is acting decisively in the national interest to support households and businesses and to address the significant economic consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic. If a person below Age Pension qualification age is unable to work, they may be eligible for an alternative social security payment. The temporary fortnightly Coronavirus Supplement applies to recipients of allowances such as the JobSeeker Payment. It recognises that the depressed job market resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic may make it more difficult for people who are, or who become, unemployed to find new work in the coming months. It is targeted at those who were most likely to have experienced a reduction in employment income, or who would have trouble in gaining employment because of COVID-19 restrictions.

The Coronavirus Supplement changed from $550 to $250 per fortnight from 25 September 2020 to reflect the gradually improving economic and labour market conditions, and to balance the level of support people are receiving with incentives to get back into the job market. More information is available at
https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/coronavirus-supplement.

As steps are taken to re-open the Australian economy, mutual obligation requirements for job seekers have re-commenced in a limited capacity for everywhere except Victoria. Most JobSeeker Payment recipients have mutual obligation requirements, which are designed to ensure that recipients are actively looking for work and are participating in activities that will help them into employment. Depending on their age and how long they have been receiving payment for, recipients aged 55 years and over may choose to satisfy their mutual obligation requirements through approved voluntary work, suitable paid work (including self-employment), or a combination of these activities. More information on mutual obligation requirements for jobseekers can be found at: www.dese.gov.au/news/mutual-obligation-requirements-job-seekers.

The Social Services Legislation Amendment (Welfare Reform) Act 2018 was passed in March 2018, as part of the modernisation of the social security system. The legislation provided for the cessation of Wife Pension and the creation of JobSeeker Payment on 20 March 2020. As part of the Government's reform of the income support system for people of working age, Wife Pension recipients who were under Age Pension age and did not qualify to receive Carer Allowance were transferred to JobSeeker Payment, which is the main income support payment for working age Australians who have capacity to work now or in the future. These recipients receive a transition rate of payment, maintained at up to the maximum Wife Pension rate as at 19 March 2020. This is higher than the JobSeeker Payment maximum rate and recipients will also retain their Pensioner Concession Card.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social services, Senator Ruston
Child Care
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 24 August 2020 regarding Petition EN1585. In response to the issues raised in the petition, I can provide the following advice.

The Australian Government is investing record funding in 2020-21 into child care to provide more support to families. This investment will increase over the next few years to more than $10 billion per year.

As part of the Child Care Package (the Package), the Government implemented the Child Care Subsidy (CCS). The CCS is designed to target financial support to lower and middle income families, with the percentage of subsidy a family is entitled to being based on combined annual family income. Families earning $69,390 or less are entitled to the maximum CCS rate of 85 per cent of the annual fee charged, or of the relevant hourly rate cap (whichever is lower) . As family income increases the rate of subsidy decreases, reaching zero per cent of $353,680. Families with incomes at or above this threshold have no CCS entitlement. While the CCS may not subsidise the total of Australian families' child care costs, it is designed to assist as many families as possible within the Government's financial limitations. This approach ensures more financial support is targeted to families who need it most to access child care.

The number of hours of subsidised care a family is entitled to per fortnight is determined by a three-step activity test, which ensures Government support for child care is better targeted to those who depend on child care to work, train, study, volunteer or participate in other recognised activities.
A broad range of activities meet the activity test requirements, including paid work, being self-employed, doing unpaid work in a family business, looking for work, volunteering or studying.

The activity test has a low entry requirement to assist parents returning to work in a graduated manner or undertaking other activities. Parents only need to undertake a minimum of eight hours of recognised activity per fortnight to access 36 hours of subsidised child care a fortnight. There are also exemptions to the activity test for parents who legitimately cannot meet the activity requirements.

In addition, the Package includes a number of mechanisms to help reduce costs for parents. For example, an hourly rate cap, which is the maximum hourly rate the Government will subsidise for each service type, effectively sets a reference point from which parents can expect prices should not dramatically exceed, and from which they can hold providers accountable. The Government has also opened up flexibility for child care providers to operate in a way that works best for their families.

The Government recognises children from disadvantaged backgrounds benefit most from quality early childhood education and care. Therefore, the Government provides additional support for families in particular circumstances . For example, under the Child Care Safety Net, families earning $69,390 or less who do not meet the activity test are entitled to 24 hours of subsidised early childhood education and care per fortnight. That is equivalent to two six hour sessions per week, subsidised at the highest 85 per cent rate. Further, the Additional Child Care Subsidy (ACCS) acts as a top up payment to the CCS which provides targeted additional fee assistance to families and children facing barriers in accessing affordable child care. ACCS fully subsidises child care in some cases where families require additional support. For instance, families transitioning to work or dealing with job loss or when they need practical help with the cost of child care to support their child's wellbeing. More information can be found at www.education.gov.au/additional-child-care-subsidy-0.

Administrative data indicates that in the March quarter 2020, around 90 percent of families receiving CCS had access to at least 72 hours of subsidised care per fortnight. Of the 933,550 families eligible for CCS:
62.6 per cent (584,050 families) could access up to 100 hours per fortnight
27.4 per cent (256,160 families) could access up to 72 hours per fortnight
4.1 per cent (38,620 families) could access a maximum of 36 hours per fortnight, which includes families eligible for the preschool exemption.

Out-of-pocket costs were less than $5 per hour per child for the parents of 71.4 per cent of children in centre based day care, and out-of-pocket costs were less than $2 per hour per child for the parents of nearly 24.0 per cent of children in centre based day care in the March quarter 2020. Australian Bureau of Statistics national data shows that nationally child care costs are 3.2 per cent lower in March 2020, than June 2018 when the CCS was introduced.

The Government's recognition of child care's critical role to supporting workforce participation, was demonstrated in its response to COVID-19. The Government's Early Childhood Education and Care Relief Package (Relief Package) was a temporary measure designed to ensure the viability of the sector whilst providing free child care to Australian families from April to mid July 2020. The Relief Package helped many families continue to participation in the workforce.

When the Government reviewed the Relief Package in May 2020, 99 per cent of the 13,400 child care services nationally were operational and supporting families with access to free child care. A survey of all approved child care services conducted in May 2020 showed that most services reported that the Relief Package, together with the JobKeeper Payment helped them to: stay open (90 per cent of services), remain financially viable (82 per cent), retain staff (91 per cent), provide child care to the children of essential workers and vulnerable children (91 per cent) and keep children enrolled (82 per cent).

The CCS and ACCS recommenced on 13 July 2020, along with a range of new measures to support the child care sector and parents as they move back to the subsidy, including a relaxed activity test for families. Families who have had their hours of activity reduced as a result of COVID-19 will be able to access up to 100 hours per fortnight of care to 4 April 2021. Beyond Victoria, demand for child care is now above pre COVID-19 levels.

A comprehensive evaluation of the child care reforms introduced in July 2018 (i.e. the Child Care Package) is underway to help monitor implementation and assess the impact of its key elements on families, providers and services. A consortium, led by the Australian Institute of Family Studies, has been engaged by the Department of Education, Skills and Employment. Affordability for families and workforce participation is a strong focus of this evaluation. Further information about the evaluation can be found at https://aifs.gov.au/projects/child­ care-package-evaluation.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of the petitioners to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Tehan
Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020 enclosing Petition EN1591 concerning parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents seeking exemption from Australia's travel restrictions. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you know, from 1 February 2020, the Australian Government has progressively announced travel restrictions to curb the introduction and spread of COVID-19 in Australia. From 20 March 2020, travel restrictions have been in place prohibiting travel into Australia of all foreign nationals, unless they fall within certain exempt categories.
The travel restrictions have been successful in slowing the spread of COVID-19 in Australia, and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

State and territory governments have taken decisions to impose health restrictions such as mandatory two weeks quarantine for all international arrivals. Unfortunately, limited hotel rooms have been made available for quarantine purposes by the state governments who administer the quarantine arrangements. The problem has been compounded by arbitrary state border closures where returning state residents are placed in hotel quarantine, taking places that would otherwise have been utilised by citizens returning from overseas.

Decisions to grant exemptions must be balanced against the Government's intent for imposing the travel restrictions, that is, the potential health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers.
The travel restrictions for persons coming to Australia do not apply to:
an Australian citizen or a permanent resident of Australia;
an immediate family member of an Australian citizen or permanent resident;
a New Zealand (NZ) citizen usually resident in Australia and their immediate family members;
a diplomat accredited to Australia (holding a subclass 995 visa) (effective 11 July 2020);
a traveller transiting Australia for 72 hours or less (effective 11 July 2020);
airline crew;
maritime crew including marine pilots; and
recruited under the Government approved Seasonal Worker Program or Pacific Labour Scheme.

The Commissioner of the Australian Border Force (ABF), Mr Michael Outram APM, or Home Affairs Departmental or ABF decision-makers may consider requests for travel on a case by case basis where there are compelling circumstances.

The exemption request should be accompanied by the individual's details, case information and supporting statement. It is important that people seeking an exemption provide evidence of a compelling case in accordance with one of the following categories:
a person travelling at the invitation of the Government or a state or territory government authority for the purpose of assisting in the COVID-19 response;
a person providing critical or specialist medical services, including air ambulance, medical evacuations and delivering critical medical supplies;

a person with critical skills required to maintain the supply of essential goods and services, such as in medical technology, critical infrastructure, telecommunications, engineering and mining, supply chain logistics, aged care, agriculture, primary industry, food production, and the maritime industry;

a person delivering services in sectors critical to Australia's economic recovery, such as financial technology, large scale manufacturing, film, media and television production and emerging technology, where no Australian worker is available;
providing critical skills in religious or theology fields;
sponsored by your employer to work in Australia in an occupation on the Priority Migration Skilled Occupation List;
a person whose entry would otherwise be in the national interest, supported by the Government or a state or territory government authority;

,
military personnel including those who form part of the Status of Forces Agreement, Commonwealth Armed Forces, Asia Pacific Forces and Status of Armed Forces Agreement;
a student completing year 11 and 12, with support from the relevant state or territory government; or
travel for compassionate and compelling reasons.

As you are aware, immediate family members of Australian citizens, Australian permanent residents and NZ citizens usually resident in Australia, are exempt from Australia's travel restrictions. Spouses, de facto partners, dependent children and legal guardians are all considered to be immediate family members for the purpose of exemptions to Australia's travel restrictions.

The parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents are not considered immediate family, having regard to the definition of immediate family under regulation 1.12AA of the Migration Regulations 1994. They can request an individual exemption if they meet one of the above categories and can provide relevant supporting documentation.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au. These measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly.
For the latest information and advice from the Government in relation to the outbreak of COVID-19, please visit: https://www.australia.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1591 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
Employment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 24 August 2020, referring Petition EN1597 about an inquiry into the protections available to casual employees under the unfair dismissal provisions of the Fair Work Act 2009 (the Act) to me as Minister for Industrial Relations.

Casual work is intended to provide a degree of flexibility for both employers and employees. Recognising that casual workers do not receive the same entitlements as part time and full time employees, most modern awards provide a casual loading of 25 per cent on top of the base rate of pay for full-time and part-time employees. Casual work is a genuine and fulfilling arrangement for many people, such as those balancing work with studying or family responsibilities. This has been the case for many decades, under many governments.

The unfair dismissal provisions of the Act provide important protections for employees and aim to ensure that a 'fair go all around' is given to the rights of employees and employers. The Act does provide some unfair dismissal protections for casual employees. These require that they were employed on a regular and systematic basis, and had a reasonable expectation of ongoing employment on that basis. These requirements are intended to strike an appropriate balance between the rights of employers and employees and arose from the introduction of the Act by the Labor Government in 2009.

Moreover, an employee's casual status does not exempt them from protection from termination for a discriminatory reason. The general protections provisions prohibit adverse action, such as dismissal and loss of shifts, by an employer against its employees for discriminatory reasons, including disability, sex, age, family or carer's responsibilities, and pregnancy. It is also unlawful to take adverse action against an employee because of the employee's workplace rights. In contrast to unfair dismissal, there is no cap on compensation in the general protections jurisdiction.

Neither the Attorney-General nor the Attorney-General's Department provides legal advice to the public. However I note that, without commenting on whether the common law recognises a general principle of equality, the Commonwealth Parliament can always override the common law where the Commonwealth has legislative power and where it clearly expresses an intention to do so in legislation.

The petition also raises the consistency of the Act's unfair dismissal provisions with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR). Australia complies with all of its obligations under international law, including under the ICCPR. Consistent with the ICCPR, Australia ensures that persons are not barred from bringing a suit against other persons by reason of their race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status. Employment standards formulated by the United Nations specialised agency the International Labour Organization (ILO) are also relevant to the issues raised in this petition. In particular, Australia has ratified the International Labour Organization's (ILO) Termination of Employment Convention 1982 (No. 158), which enables workers engaged on a casual basis for a short period to be exempt from unfair dismissal laws.
The Government considers the existing arrangements under the Act to provide appropriate protections for the rights of casual employees.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Porter
Facial Recognition Technology
Dear MrO'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020 enclosing Petition EN1600 concerning the use of facial recognition technology in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government is committed to keeping Australians and their personal information safe. The Government's investment in, and use of, facial recognition technology is essential to Australia's security and economic interests. It is vital to the management of Australia's border to help to protect people from identity crime, and is becoming increasingly important for improving Government service delivery, including to victims of natural disasters.

Being able to reliably establish identity is an important element of the Government's commitment to strengthening the identity security of Australians, through the National Identity Security Strategy. The Department of Home Affairs is leading implementation of new biometric face matching services in accordance with the Intergovernmental Agreement on Identity Matching Services, agreed by the Commonwealth and all state and territory governments in October 2017.

The Government has also introduced primary legislation to improve privacy protections and transparency measures as they relate to the sharing of personal information through the services, to ensure the rights of all Australians are protected. The Identity-matching Services Bill 2019 (the Bill) is currently before the Parliament, and will give effect to the Commonwealth's commitments under the Intergovernmental Agreement. The legislation was referred to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security. The Government is carefully considering the Committee's report on the Bill to strengthen privacy safeguards over the operation of these services.

Identity crime continues to be one of the most common and costly crimes in Australia. According to the latest statistics compiled by the Australian Institute of Criminology, identity crime costs over AUD2 billion per year, impacts one in 10 Australians each year, and affects one in four Australians over their lifetime. The face matching services established by the Intergovernmental Agreement will reduce the risk of identity theft and fraud in the community, and improve the delivery of key government services, including disaster relief and income support, while maintaining the integrity of these programs.

Privacy and ethics are at the forefront of the Government's use of facial recognition. The Government is committed to demonstrating a high standard of privacy governance, and are steadfast in the ethical use of biometric technology, in accordance with all applicable laws, including the Privacy Act 1988. The Government is equally committed to ensuring that the facial recognition technology being used is as accurate as possible. The Government continues to work with national and international biometric testing bodies to improve the accuracy of its biometric systems. According to recent independent testing, the facial recognition technology used by Commonwealth Government agencies, including the Department, is among the most accurate in the world.

The Government understands the concerns raised around facial recognition technology, and the prospect of real-time monitoring of people in public places (sometimes referred to as 'mass surveillance'). Put simply, the technology deployed through the face matching services cannot be used in this way. The system is deliberately designed not to accept live video feeds, such as CCTV.

Additionally, only a specified list of law enforcement, anti-corruption and security agencies may use the Government's services to identify people. It is therefore not possible for private sector organisations, such as operators of stadiums, or local government authorities to use the face matching services provided by the Department to scan a crowd to identify people. As a further safeguard , the Intergovernmental Agreement stresses that the services are not to be used as the sole basis for ascertaining a person's identity for evidentiary purposes.

All of the Government's activities in this important area of public interest are subject to a range of existing oversight bodies. These include the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, and the Australian Commissioner for Law Enforcement Integrity.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1600 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mr Dutton
Family Law
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 August 2020 regarding Petition No EN1605, presented to the Standing Committee on Petitions, raising concerns about parenting arrangements after family relationship breakdown and the collection of child support.

The Government has established a Joint Select Committee to inquire into the family law system. For those going through the family law system, it is important that the systems they have to go through work as best as they can. Family breakdown is a risk factor for suicide, it is a time when family violence can escalate and it warrants this level of attention.

The terms of reference for the inquiry are broad and allow for the examination of a range of matters that have a real and practical impact on Australian families. The inquiry allows for an examination of the complicated interaction of the family law system with the child support system. The inquiry also provides for a careful examination of the financial costs to families involved in family law proceedings, and options to ensure that costs, including legal fees, are proportionate to the issues in dispute. The inquiry will further look at the impacts of family law proceedings on the health, safety and wellbeing of children and families involved in those proceedings.

On 7 October 2020, the Committee released an interim report covering a broad range of topics, including issues of relevance to the petition, such as, the interaction between Australia's Child Support Scheme and the family law system; enforcement of parenting orders; and arbitration, mediation and other forms of alternative dispute resolution. The Committee is scheduled to deliver its final report by the last sitting day in February 2021. The interim report, the Committee's terms of reference and further information about the inquiry are available from the Committee's website at:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Family_Law_System .

With respect to the specific elements of your petition, although the child support scheme recognises a parent's obligation to provide support for their child is not tied to the other parent's compliance with a court order or parenting agreement that specifies care arrangements, there are provisions within the child support legislation to assist in deterring parents from contravening court orders and parenting agreements.
These provisions were strengthened through the Family Assistance and Child Support Legislation Amendment (Protecting Children) Act 2018.

For court-ordered arrangements, the percentage of care used to determine the child support assessment can continue to be based on the order for an interim period of up to 52 weeks from the date the order started, if the disputed care change occurs within the first year of the order. For older court orders, the interim period can be up to 26 weeks, or up to 14 weeks if the person with increased care takes reasonable action to participate in family dispute resolution.

For care arrangements in a non-enforceable agreement or parenting plan, the interim period can be up to 14 weeks, or up to four weeks if the care change occurs after the first year of the agreement or plan and the person with increased care takes reasonable action to participate in family dispute resolution.

The Family Law Act 1975 does not make specific provision for relocation of children or parents following separation. As with other parenting arrangements, where relocation is in issue, the parties are encouraged to agree on the best outcome for their children. Where a relocation matter progresses to a family law court, the court will examine a range of considerations in deciding which parenting orders are proper. In deciding these matters, the court must regard the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration.

Under the Family Law Act, parents retain parental responsibility for children under the age of 18 after separation, subject to court orders. If a parent decides to unilaterally relocate a child, a family court may make orders requiring that the child be returned. In considering orders to that effect, the court will consider what is in the best interests of the child. In the event that a parent unilaterally relocates a child domestically and the court makes orders for the return of the child, either on an interim or final basis, and the parent refuses to return the child, the court may make recovery orders, seeking the assistance of the Australian Federal Police to return the child.

International parental child abduction is an offence under sections 65Y, 65YA, 65Z and 65ZAA of the Family Law Act. The provisions cover removing and retaining a child overseas in breach of a court order or where parenting proceedings are pending before a court, subject to certain exceptions. The offences are punishable by a penalty of up to three years' imprisonment.

While the petition suggests prohibiting relocation would encourage parents to engage in mediation, separating couples are encouraged to resolve issues themselves without going to court. If they can resolve their differences without going to court they are likely to save themselves time, money and stress.

The Family Law Act requires separated couples needing to resolve parenting arrangements to make a genuine effort at family dispute resolution before attending court, unless one of the exceptions applies, such as family violence, child abuse or urgency. The Government funds a range of legal and other services that provide information and assist individuals, and their families with family law issues, including family dispute resolution services.

In its review of the family law system, the ALRC recommended amendments to the Family Law Act to allow some children's matters to be arbitrated (recommendation 28). The Government is considering and will respond to the ALRC's recommendations.

As noted above, the Family Law Act requires separated couples needing to resolve parenting arrangements to make a genuine effort at family dispute resolution before attending court, unless an exception applies, such as family violence, child abuse or urgency. Specifically, where the court is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been or would be a risk of abuse of the child if there were to be a delay in applying for a court order, or this would place a party at risk of family violence.

These exceptions ensure that separating couples are not required to attend family dispute resolution in circumstances that would be unsafe or inappropriate. They also protect those at immediate risk of violence or abuse from delays in attending court.

The Family Law Act provides a legal framework for resolving arrangements for children and property following a relationship breakdown. The 'best interests of the child' is the paramount consideration when resolving parenting matters. This includes the need to protect children from harm and, in the absence of factors such as violence or abuse, for children to enjoy a meaningful relationship with each of their parents.

In cases of high conflict or where there is a perceived or actual risk to a child if they were to spend unsupervised time with a parent, the family courts may order supervised contact visits. The court must be satisfied that those orders are in the child's best interests. In some cases a court may order supervised visits where a child is being introduced or reintroduced to a parent or family member with whom they have spent little or no time.

The Australian Government funds Children's Contact Services to help parents comply with such orders and for children from separated families to establish or maintain a relationship with the parent with whom they do not live.
Family law cases are often complex and, in each individual case, the facts need to be considered by the court and a decision made on those facts.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Porter
Teachers: Mental Health
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 24 August 2020 referring a copy of petition number EN1613. The petition requests that every teacher be trained to support students with mental health issues . I present the below response for consideration by the Standing Committee on Petitions.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of educators being able to support the mental health and wellbeing of students, including providing support to students who have experienced trauma.

The Australian Professional Standards for Teachers (the Teacher Standards) provide a nationally agreed quality assurance mechanism against which teachers can be assessed to ensure they have the competencies required to be effective educators.

The Teacher Standards are a public statement of what constitutes quality teaching and define what teachers should know and be able to do at different stages across their careers (Graduate, Proficient, Highly Accomplished and Lead). The Teacher Standards comprise three domains: Professional Knowledge, Professional Practice and Professional Engagement, each with a number of standards that articulate the knowledge, skills and attributes required across the four career stages. Standard 4 - Create and maintain supportive and safe learning environments includes strategies to support students' wellbeing and safety.

The Teacher Standards also underpin national approaches to the accreditation of initial teacher education programs, the registration of teachers and the formal certification of Highly Accomplished and Lead Teachers. All states and territories have linked the Teacher Standards to registration requirements, and some make reference to the Teacher Standards in professional learning requirements for teachers.

The Government recognises that the states, territories and the non-government schooling sector have day-to-day responsibility for the management of Australian schools and employment of teachers. Responsibility for setting priorities for teacher professional learning sits with state and territory teacher regulatory authorities, government and non-government education departments, schools and their teaching staff .

The Student Wellbeing Hub at www.studentwellbeinghub.edu.au provides a range of freely available information and resources for educators, students and parents to assist them to create and maintain a safe and supportive school environment. It includes over 500 free resources and professional learning opportunities for teachers, as well as a dedicated area for parents and a collection of age-appropriate activities and resources for students in Foundation to Year 12. The Hub includes resources exploring the impact of complex trauma in children and considerations for educators.

The Government has also committed $8 million through Beyond Blue, through the existing national mental health in education initiative 'Be You', to develop the Bushfire Response Program. The program has engaged 25 Contact Liaison Officers to work closely with local schools and early childhood services in bushfire-affected communities to connect them to local mental health and wellbeing services and supports, provide trauma informed information and learning, and support recovery planning.
Thank you for raising this matter with me. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Tehan
Higher Education
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 19 October 2020 enclosing a petition, PET EN1665 regarding the Job-ready Graduates package (the package) of reforms to higher education.
On 19 October 2020, the Parliament passed the Higher Education Support Amendment (Job Ready Graduates and Supporting Regional and Remote Students) Bill 2020. Commencing next year:
There will be more university places for Australian students, growing to 100,000 additional places in 10 years_
Regional students and regional universities will benefit from additional support worth more than $400 million, including access to a $5,000 Tertiary Access Payment to help with relocation costs.

Students will pay less to study in areas of expected future job demand, with discounted fees for teaching, nursing, clinical psychology, English, languages, agriculture, maths, science, health, architecture, environmental science, information technology and engineering.
A $900 million National Priorities and Industry Linkage Fund will support universities to work with local industry to produce job-ready graduates.

Australian Government funding to the university sector is at a record high. This package will not reduce the level of funding the Government provides to universities. In fact, it provides more funding and certainty for universities. University funding will grow by $2 billion to 2024 and locks in indexation at pre-COVID rates for the next three years.

To be able to support Australians through the COVID-19 pandemic, the higher education system must adapt. Demand for higher education increases during economic slowdowns and students seek job relevant skills to help them enter and re-enter the workforce. The package supports increased demand from school leavers and provides more options for upskilling and reskilling workers who have lost employment due to COVID -19.

It also seeks to bridge the gap in attainment rates between regional and remote students, and metropolitan students; drive productivity for the regions; and bolster the research capacity of regional universities. All Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students from regional areas upon admission to their university of choice will have funding of a Commonwealth supported place. These reforms respond to the National Regional, Rural and Remote Tertiary Education Strategy.

On top of the additional funding provided as part of these important reforms, the 2020-21 Budget provides over $1.2 billion to support the university research sector to ensure the ongoing capability and excellence of Australian research. This includes an additional $1 billion in 2021 to alleviate the immediate financial pressures on universities caused by the reduction of international students who are unable to enter Australia as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Budget also provides $550 million for 12,000 extra university places and 50,000 short course places for Australians to upskill or reskill.
Further information about the Job-ready Graduates package or 2020-21 Budget measures can be found on the Department of Education, Skills and Employment's website at www.dese.gov.au/job-ready.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Tehan
Abdominoplasty Surgery
Dear Chair
I refer to your letter of 7 October 2020 concerning petition EN1751, requesting the reinstatement of Medicare benefits for abdominoplasty for post-partum women.

I sympathise with those who have been diagnosed with rectus diastasis following pregnancy. The decision not to provide Medicare Benefit Schedule (MBS) rebates for abdominoplasty for correction of diastasis recti in post-partum women is based on the recommendation of the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) after it considered the lack of evidence concerning the procedure in April 2015 and again in November 2019.

The MSAC appraises new medical services and provides advice to me on whether they should be publicly funded based on an assessment of its comparative safety, clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness, using the best available evidence. In 2015 and 2019 the MSAC found that although abdominoplasty had benefits for weight loss patients, there was insufficient evidence to justify Medicare funding of abdominoplasty for diastasis recti in post-partum women. Further information on the considerations of MSAC can be found at: www.msac. gov.au using the search term 'abdominoplasty'.

The Australian Society of Plastic Surgeons (ASPS) has notified my Department that they intend to submit a new application to MSAC requesting public funding for abdominoplasty for post-partum women suffering severe diastasis recti. Patients may wish to contact ASPS via email at: info@plasticsurgey.org.au to determine when they intend to submit the application.

Those diagnosed with diastasis recti following pregnancy may be interested to know that they can choose to be treated free-of-charge in the public hospital system. As public hospitals are the responsibility of state and territory governments patients may wish to contact their relevant state or territory health department to determine what support and services may be available to them.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt
Mobile Coverage
I refer to your email of 1 September 2020 regarding Petition PN0476, which relates to residents' concerns from residents of Repton, NSW about the level of mobile phone reception in their area.
My Department has reviewed the coverage maps published by Optus, Telstra and TPG Telecom, and these confirm that 3G and 4G mobile reception is variable in some locations in the Repton area.

There are a number of factors that can interfere with mobile reception at any given time or place, including in the Repton area. These factors include distance from mobile base stations, terrain, buildings (including their internal structure) and other physical obstacles such as trees interrupting the line-of-sight from the nearest mobile base station.

A number of products are available to improve mobile reception, including external antennae and authorised signal boosters and repeaters. Wi-Fi calling is also available on the mobile carriers' networks for use with a compatible device, allowing some customers to call and text over a Wi-Fi connection. This can be particularly helpful in areas that have poor indoor coverage. I encourage the residents of Repton to contact their mobile service provider to identify ways to improve their mobile reception and to obtain further advice regarding Wi-Fi calling.

Through its $380 million Mobile Black Spot Program, the Government is supporting investment in mobile infrastructure where the commercial incentives are otherwise insufficient for the carriers. The Government's commitment has to date generated a total investment of more than $836 million in more than 1,200 mobile base stations across Australia.

The Government intends that the next step in the Program will be to conduct a Round 5A, which will open for applications shortly. Funding has also been allocated for Round 6, which will commence after the competitive assessment process for Round 5A is complete.

My Department maintains a central register of locations that have been the subject of a complaint concerning poor or non-existent mobile coverage, and this register will be made available to all applicants when they are applying for funding under future rounds of the Program. Repton has been added to this register following receipt of the petition.

Ultimately, it is a commercial decision for the Mobile Network Operators (MNOs) as to whether to invest in further mobile infrastructure in the Repton area and whether to apply for funding under the Program. Community members may therefore wish to contact their local council and the MNOs to make their coverage issues known. Past experience has shown that when local communities and councils engage with the MNOs, it increases the likelihood that an application for Mobile Black Spot funding for a specific location will be submitted. I enclose the MNOs' contact details for reference.

I also note the petitioners' concerns regarding landline outages during emergencies. The Government takes issues related to emergency communications very seriously, and has announced a $37.1 million package to prevent, mitigate and manage telecommunications emergency outages. This package includes four elements:
$18 million for mobile network hardening, including increased power backup
$10 million for temporary telco infrastructure deployments
$7 million for better telecommunications for rural and country fire service depots and evacuation centres
$2.1 million to improve Government information to communities about access to telecommunications in emergencies

These measures form a key part of the Government' s $650 million program for locally-led bushfire recovery and will increase network resilience and preparedness so communities can better deal with future emergencies and natural disasters. Further information on the package is available at www.communications.gov.au/phone/improving-resilience-australias-telco-networks.

It is important to understand that no communications technology can provide 100 per cent resilience, as any communication system can be temporarily affected by adverse conditions, particularly during a power outage or natural disaster. It is therefore strongly recommended that, as part of effective emergency preparation and planning, people do not rely on a single form of communication or source of information during an emergency.

The New South Wales Rural Fire Service website provides guidance on how to best plan and prepare for the bushfire season, including advice about where to find information and check for warnings and alerts. Further information is available at www.rfs.nsw.gov.au/plan-and-prepare.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Regional Health, Regional Communications and Local Government

PETITIONS
Statements

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:02): You will have noted that there has been some increased interest in petitioning of late. This interest has also seen an increase in civic engagement in petitioning, which the committee warmly welcomes.

The committee is aware of its responsibility to provide an open and accessible petitioning system, and we are committed to ensuring this. We are also aware that some improvements could be made to the current system so that all users have the best possible experience, whether they are creating or signing a petition, or just looking for information.

Citizens will therefore be pleased to know that a project is underway to increase the capacity of the e-petitioning system to better handle peaks in user engagement and to improve the accessibility of petitioning information more generally.
Improvements will include:
easy English language to explain the petitioning process and rules for petitions;
symbols and imagery to increase accessibility and understanding of petitioning processes;
an updated and comprehensive 'frequently asked questions' page;
a streamlined process for creating paper and e-petitions with improved guidance at each step; and
enhanced web design and navigation tools so that users can easily find what they are looking for.
I look forward to further updating the House on the work of the committee and this project.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2019

p.span: National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2019
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Wilkie.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr WILKIE (Clark) (10:05): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2019 will amend the National Consumer Credit Protection Act 2009 to provide better protections for consumers from small amount credit contracts, commonly known as payday loans, and consumer leases, commonly known as rent-to-buy schemes. The bill will impose a cap on rent-to-buy schemes, require payday loans to have equal repayment amounts and payment intervals, remove monthly fee charges where the payday loan has been repaid early and in full, prevent marketing of rent-to-buy schemes at people's homes, create stronger laws to ensure compliance and increase penalties for noncompliance.

If that all sounds very familiar to members in this House, it's because in this place we have tried time and time again to bring about these reforms, including the government showing an interest in these reforms at one stage. I remind honourable members that it was way back in 2015 that the federal government announced a review of payday lending laws and regulated consumer leases, and it organised for an inquiry to be conducted. The final report of that inquiry was handed down in March 2016. One thing led to another, and the government released an exposure draft of the National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2017 late in that year. However, that bill never came to fruition. In addition to the government's early effort, there have been numerous attempts by the opposition and by crossbenchers, both in this place and in the other place, all of which have failed to progress.

It beggars belief that, after so much talk and so much effort by so many people, we still have not provided the protection for consumers that they desperately need and will need even more as we go into the post-pandemic world and as government income support payments are reduced. Experts, including ASIC in front of Senate estimates just recently, have made the point that there will be likely an increased reliance by consumers on payday loans and rent-to-buy schemes. So, frankly, it beggars belief that we are not onto this. Really, there's no good reason that, if we really did want to bring about this reform, we couldn't have this bill through both houses of parliament in this sitting fortnight. That would be the right thing to do by the community. That would mean we would go into next year, when government support payments are reducing, with greater protection for consumers. Let's not forget: this is about members of the community. I could stand up here and give countless examples of the harm that these payday loans and rent-to-buy schemes are causing. I have limited time, but I'll give one or two examples.

There's the case study of a single mother, with three children, whose main income is from Centrelink. She was lonely at night and began gambling online, which she funded via obtaining payday loans from eight different online payday lenders. The bank statements she provided when applying for those loans clearly showed where she was spending her money: on gambling. In fact, most of the money on those statements was clearly going to other payday lenders for gambling and also to a debt collection agency. On the consumer checklist, the lender Ferratum made a number of false claims, and she continued to be issued loans. When Ferratum eventually declined her a loan, they sent her request to another payday lender, Cigno, without her permission. Cigno then advanced her a loan. She approached her bank, Westpac, and asked them to cancel her direct debits to payday lenders, but Westpac refused, saying she would need to contact them directly even though banks can cancel direct debits. When this unfortunate woman finally engaged a counsellor, she was struggling with bills and life in general. She became homeless and remains homeless.

I have another quick example. A 17-year-old, who had been diagnosed with psychosis and has been homeless for over six months, applied and was approved for a payday loan of $250 to cover her daily expenses. However, she was hospitalised due to a deterioration in her mental health and was in recovery for several months. Over that year her debt, which started at $250, escalated to $770 with fees and interest added each week. I'm pleased to report that after engaging a financial counsellor this person was able to get the debt waived on account of the irresponsible lending from the service provider.

I could go on and on and on about this issue, and I'm sure honourable members in this place have heard many examples themselves. It beggars belief why we're not doing this. But not only are we not bringing about these reforms; the government wants to go one worse and actually wind back responsible lending laws. The government's National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Supporting Economic Recovery) Bill 2020 will scrap responsible lending laws for banks which were introduced after the GFC, shifting back to a 'borrower beware' model, even though a coalition of 125 peak financial institutions have come out strongly opposing these changes. I'm painting a pretty grim picture here. I'm painting a picture of a government that five years ago indicated an interest in cracking down on payday loans and has done nothing about it. I'm painting a picture of a government that not only is doing nothing about payday and rent-to-buy schemes but is now ploughing ahead with cutting back on the very sensible consumer credit protections that were introduced after the GFC.

I think we're forgetting what our job is in this place. It's to help, support and protect our constituents. I make the point again: I'm sure I could get the opposition to support this private member's bill. The opposition, to its credit, has tried to progress these matters on a number of occasions in the past. Through you, Speaker, I call on the government to get behind this private member's bill. Let's see it through both houses of parliament over this sitting fortnight so that when the community goes into 2021, as government income support washes off and people are at risk from these predators even more, they have the protections they need. In my remaining time, I invite the member for Mayo, who is generously seconding this bill and has done a lot of work in this space herself over several years, to make a few additional comments.

Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (10:12): I'm very grateful to second the National Consumer Credit Protection Amendment (Small Amount Credit Contract and Consumer Lease Reforms) Bill 2020. I can't think of a bill that has been presented to the parliament more than this bill. The government talked about it. Labor have presented their private member's bill. It's been presented in the Senate. I have presented it. I think the former member for Indi actually presented a bill, and now it's the member for Clark.

We are letting Australians down when we don't act with respect to predatory payday lending. I actually want to touch on something that is related to payday lending, and that is Afterpay. Afterpay is a tsunami waiting to happen. We had a 90 per cent increase in use in the last year. We had one in five consumers using Afterpay receiving late fees, and, when they need to take out a loan to pay those late fees, where do they go? They go to get a small loan credit contract, and then they pay up to a 200 per cent increase. We're talking about $43 million in late fees with respect to Afterpay. We need to do work in this place with respect to Afterpay and with respect to payday lending. We are doing the greatest of disservice to Australians by not acting. The fact is that this is the government's own legislation and for many years now frustrated members of parliament have taken the government's own work into this place and said, 'C'mon, let's work on this; let's do this together,' yet we don't even have enough members in the chamber here to make quorum. It's a shame. We need to do better in this place on this very important work. I urge the government to actually make it happen.
The SPEAKER: The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Amendment (Common Sense Partner Visa) Bill 2020

p.span: Migration Amendment (Common Sense Partner Visa) Bill 2020
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Hill.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr HILL (Bruce) (10:16): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
To be honest, Mr Speaker, I never wanted to have to introduce the Migration Amendment (Common Sense Partner Visa) Bill 2020.
The minister has had the power to fix these issues and should have done so months ago with the stroke of his pen, by amending the Migration Regulations.

But, mysteriously, on Saturday night—just before I introduce this bill, a Deidre Chambers style coincidence and after a week of negative media stories—Minister Tudge panicked and sneakily updated the Home Affairs website to say he would do something in "early 2021".
This is just more spin! Typical of this hopeless government. Make an announcement with no action, and hope the problem goes away.
This is too little, too late. Parliament could take action today, by passing this very simple bill.

All it does is allow people, who are already in Australia, to stay here with their partners and loved ones and have their offshore partner visa granted in Australia, instead of having to fly overseas and back again in the middle of a pandemic.
Literally, that's it. That's all this bill does.
The minister's current regulations contain what could be called the FOFI rule—fly out, fly in.
The rule requires applicants for partner visas who originally applied offshore, who are ALREADY in Australia, to leave Australia for their visa to be granted.
Traditionally people took a quick trip to New Zealand or Bali for the weekend and come back when their visa was ready to be granted.
Yet we are now in the middle of a global pandemic! We don't want people taking risky trips overseas if they don't have to.
Transiting through international airports and hotels, then flying back to Australia to quarantine.
Right now, over 36,000 Australians are still stranded overseas, desperate to come home.
The Prime Minister keeps making announcements about them—he promised they'd be home by Christmas—but it's all spin. The queue just gets longer.
The marketing department over there that masquerades as a government blames the states and quarantine capacity.

Nothing is ever the Prime Minister's responsibility. He's just a powerless and impotent little man, a daggy dad in a baseball cap—until there's credit to be snatched then he pops up on TV and wraps himself in the flag.

Yet, the Morrison government is itself wasting precious quarantine places, by forcing the partners of Australian citizens—people who are already safe here in Australia—to make risky and expensive return trips overseas just so the computer will spit out their partner visa.
This bill will stop this madness immediately, today.
Preserving quarantine spots for those Aussies still stranded overseas who are desperate to come home for Christmas.
And saving people from risking their health and exposure to COVID-19 overseas, and trashing their savings on an expensive, pointless trip.
The government has known about this problem for months and I honestly don't know why the minister has failed to fix it. Seriously. It's not rocket science even for this mob.
But after a year of failure all we get now is a vague announcement on a Saturday night that he might start thinking about it next year. It's government by spin.

Instead of providing certainty to the thousands of Australians and their loved ones who have waited years for their visas, Saturday's announcement raises more questions than it answers.
